subject: Thanks
msgSnippet: Thanks Eric, I will try to get these books first. Once again thanks for prompt reply. Regards, Pankaj ... From: Eric Vought  To:
messageBody:
Thanks Eric,
I will try to get these books first.
Once again thanks for prompt reply.
Regards,

Pankaj


----- Original Message -----
From: Eric Vought <evought@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, September 03, 2001 7:13 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Unit test release procedure


> Pankaj:
>
> Two books that should help:
>
> _The Craft of Software Testing_ by Brian Merrick published by Prentice
> Hall
>
> and
>
> _Automated Software Testing, Introduction, Management and Performance_
> by Elfriede Dustin, Jeff Rashka and John Paul published by Addison Wesley.
>
> Neither of these books talk about JUnit per se, but I have found them
> particularly useful for giving one a background in the practice of
> testing, automation, and QA overall. The first book goes into a lot of
> detail about what to test, how to approach testing it, how to set and
> verify reasonable goals, etc. The second gives a high level view of how
> test automation and regression fits into the whole picture. The two
> together should give you a good start on what you need. The second book
> includes templates for appropriate process artifacts.
>
> On Mon, 3 Sep 2001, Pankaj Solanki wrote:
>
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I am a newcomer to testing world.I will be using JUnit3.7 tool for unit
testing.
> > At present my assignment is to write unit test release procedure.
> >
> > Will you please help me out in this activity such as:
> > how to proceed, what to include, how the code passes from developers to
tester or
> > do we have any templates / design guides for this ?
> >
> > I already checked in site www.junit.org for articles/documentation, but
its not of my use for the task at hand.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Pankaj Solanki
> >
> >
>
> --
> Eric Vought
> Chief Technical Officer - QLUE Consulting, Inc.
